item.title: The Square Root Trick
item.description: When you run into the indeterminate form([[/notes/Indeterminate Forms in Limits|Indeterminate Forms and Dealing with Them]]) $\frac{0}{0}$ while taking the limit of a function $f$ and either the numerator or denominator of the function is in the form $a + b\sqrt{c}$, you can just multiply both sides of the fraction with $a-b\sqrt{c}$ and then calculate the limit from there.

item.title: The Squeeze Theorem
item.description: When you take three funtions $f(x)$, $g(x)$ and $h(x)$ such that $f(x) \le g(x) \le h(x)$, but you can’t calculate the limit of the function $g(x)$ at a value $c$, you can simply calculate $\lim_{x\to c} f(x)$ and $\lim_{x\to c} h(x)$.

item.title: Indeterminate Forms and Dealing with Them
item.description: An indeterminate form in calculus is an equation which doesn’t have a value. Such as $\frac{0}{0}$ or $\frac{\infty}{\infty}$ or $0 \times \infty$.
